Dr. George Martin, President, received a housing allowance and reimbursement for life insurance per employment contract. Both the housing allowance and life insurance are taxable and reported to Dr. Martin on IRS Form W-2.

George E. Martin: The University established a non-qualified deferred compensation plan under IRS Code Section 457F for the purpose of providing a retirement benefit for the university President, George E. Martin. Under the terms of the plan, the university agreed to establish a non-vested retirement account in a financial institution of the university's selection in the name of the university on behalf of the President; make an annual contribution to the retirement account during the term of the plan; invest the account balance and distribute the account balance to the President in accordance with the occurrence of specific events. The President has no rights to or interest in the retirement account prior to the date the account becomes payable to the President under the terms and conditions set for in the plan. The President's right to the retirement benefits is non-vested and forfeitable prior to the payment date. The retirement account is the property of the university at all times prior to the payment date. The university accrued $22,740 and contributed $93,000 into the plan in the current reporting period. The President will become 100 percent vested in and entitled to payment of the retirement account at his normal retirement date; upon termination for disability or death; other than cause and voluntary cause for good reason as defined. The President forfeits all interest in the retirement account in the event of termination for cause or voluntary termination for other than good reason as defined. During the current reporting period, the President received his distribution of the 457F plan under the terms of his contract in the amount of $790,356.82. This amount includes previously reported contributions and accruals by the University of $537,060 and current reporting period contributions and accruals of $115,740. The remaining balance of $137,556.82 represents re-invested interest and dividends along with accumulated gains net of fees. During the current reporting period, the following individuals received payments under the university's early retirement program. This program was offered to select faculty and staff members. Frank Krafka, Jr.: taxable compensation of $144,330. Paul T. Newton: taxable compensation of $110,592. Raymond J. Spinhirne: taxable compensation of $127,294.

George E. Martin: Included in Column B [iii] is a taxable housing allowance of $45,000, taxable automobile allowance of $4,068, taxable long-term disability insurance of $380, contribution to IRS 457(b) plan of $18,000, taxable employer provided life insurance greater than $50,000 of $4,944, payment of IRS 457(f) plan deferred compensation of $790,357 and taxable reimbursements of $17,450. The payments of the taxable reimbursements, automobile allowance, long-term disability insurance, deferred compensation and housing allowance are made pursuant to the terms of the contract with President Martin and the university. During the current reporting period, the President received his distribution of the IRS 457(f) plan under the terms of his contract in the amount of $790,357. This amount includes previously reported contributions and accruals by the University of $537,060 and current reporting period contributions and accruals of $115,740. The remaining balance of $137,557 represents re-invested interest and dividends along with accumulated gains net of fees. Frank Krafka, Jr.: Included in Column B [iii] is a taxable compensation of $144,330 resulting from participation in the faculty early retirement program. This program was offered to select faculty members. Paul T. Newton: Included in Column B [iii] is a taxable compensation of $110,592 resulting from participation in the faculty early retirement program. This program was offered to select faculty members. Raymond J. Spinhirne: Included in Column B [iii] is a taxable compensation of $127,294 resulting from participation in the staff early retirement program. This program was offered to select staff members.

This benefit was not treated as taxable income. B Travel for companions For all employees, the universitys travel policy provides reimbursement for incremental travel expenses of a spouse or other companion when there is a legitimate business purpose for their attendance and written authorization is obtained. Three members of executive management were provided with travel for companions in accordance with the universitys travel policy. This benefit was not treated as taxable income. This benefit is not treated as taxable income. Five officers were provided housing allowances which were treated as taxable income. Social club dues are paid for a limited number of members of executive management for the purpose of providing a venue conducive to the success of alumni and university business-related activities. The decision to make these payments was approved by the Chancellor for senior executives and by the Chairman of the Board of Trustees for the Chancellor. This benefit was not treated as taxable income. - The universitys School of Medicine is organized into major Departments. Each department has a faculty compensation plan that provides guidelines to the Chair of the Department for setting annual compensation of the individual faculty members. Three of the five highest compensated employees listed in Part VII, Section A of the Form 990 are faculty in a department that had salaries determined under departmental guidelines that provide for base salaries that are fixed payments. In these departments however, there are elements of compensation under the guidelines that are not fixed payments or determined by fixed formula. The Chair of the Department determines, in full or in part, the amount of this element based on the employees performance. Further, there is an element expressed as a percent of net surplus generated by the efforts of the employee. The universitys Chief Investment Officer also receives a fixed payment based on the net earnings of an activity of the university. See discussion of Part I, line 7 below for further information.

- An incentive arrangement between the university and its Chief Investment Officer was amended and restated during fiscal year 2012. The agreement provides for three components of compensation two of which are based upon a fixed formula, and one of which is based on qualitative factors. The level of the latter component is determined at the discretion of a governing board under authority assigned by the university Board of Trustees to oversee management of the universitys endowment.

- Eleven of the officers listed in Part VII of the Form 990 received payments under initial employment agreements during fiscal year 2016. None were a disqualified person with respect to the university prior to entering into their employment agreements. The employment agreements with these individuals provided for a substantial portion or all of the compensation reported in Form 990, Part VII. All amounts, except for an amount paid under the incentive agreement with the CIO discussed above, are fixed payments and subject to the initial contract exception described in Regulation 53.4958-7a3.

- The 2016 compensation payments referred to in line 8 above were subject to rebuttable presumption procedures described in Regulation section 53.4958-6c but the initial contracts under which they were paid were not.

- Other reportable compensation for Timothy Eberlein includes a distribution of amounts under a supplemental retirement plan. The amount was earned over an 8 year period commencing in 2006 and aggregated 111,255.57.

The president of the college lives in an off-campus house the rental value of which is reported as taxable compensation in accordance with applicable laws. The college covers the costs of routine utilities, routine home maintenance and repair, lawn services, and snow removal for the college owned-property. The president is reimbursed for reasonable travel expenses, as determined by the college in its sole discretion, incurred by his spouse to the extent that she accompanies him in the performance of his duties. Such reimbursements will be added to the president's taxable income, when appropriate, in accordance with applicable tax laws. Two employees have a membership to a local country club paid for by the college; the president and the vice president - college advancement. The business purpose is for the entertainment of potential donors to the college or other important guests. The fair value of personal usage, if any, is added to the employee's taxable compensation in accordance with applicable tax law.

The president's contract contains a long-term nonqualified deferred compensation plan. Deferred compensation totaling $31,000 was accrued as of 6/30/16; no amounts were contributed during calendar year 2015. Additionally, the president's contract contains a provision for certain termination benefits. For termination under certain conditions, the provisions include continuation of current salary at the rate in effect as of the date of termination for the lesser of 12 months following the termination date or the expiration of his current contract.
A pay-for-performance bonus was paid to certain college administrators and staff. Such payments were based on their annual evaluation and decided by their supervisor.

- All travel for companions of the President is approved by the Board. - Some officers and key employees received tuition reimbursements which are grossed up and reported as a taxable benefit. - The President's written contract includes housing as a condition of employment. It also includes monthly dues for one social club membership for the purpose of conducting college business. No personal social activities are conducted at the social club, therefore, the dues are not included in taxable income. Cleaning services to the President's house are provided as maintenance of a campus owned building, which is used for institutional events as well as being the personal residence of the President and family. No material services are performed in the private use portion of the residence, therefore, the value of the services is not included in taxable compensation. - The Dean of Students receives a housing benefit which is not taxable as it meets the convenience of the employer exception.
President Bettison-Varga participated in a supplemental non-qualified retirement plan. No payments were received during the calendar year.
The compensation committee recommends bonuses based on annual performance and recommendations are approved by the board.

The President is provided housing as a condition of employment for the convenience of the College. The cost of housing is excluded from compensation under IRC Section 119(d). Maintenance, landscaping and housekeeping of this College owned property is provided by the College consistent with all college owned property.
Bonus amounts are approved by President.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES HOUSING AND WEEKLY HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES TO THE PRESIDENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER SO THAT THE PRESIDENT CAN PERFORM ESSENTIAL COLLEGE BUSINESS AND ACTIVITIES AT THE HOME.

Schedule J, Part I, line 1a Housing Allowance or Residence The President of Washington College is provided housing as a condition of his/her employment. A house is provided on campus for the convenience of the College to enable the President to respond to emergent situations 24/7. Travel for Companions The president's husband is expected to join the president on bona fide college business and other purposes for the benefit of the college on occasion. The college recognizes this is a benefit to the business and will cover those qualified expenses. Tax Indemnification and Gross-ups payments Certain Officers of Washington College receive minor tax gross-up payments, amounts of which are included as taxable compensation and disclosed in column B (III). Health or Social Club Dues The President of Washington College is reimbursed the cost of social club dues. To the extent that the President uses the club for personal purposes, the value of the benefit is included in his/her taxable income. Personal Services The President of the College received nominal housekeeping and chauffer services. The personal services are provided as a business need. Housekeeping services are for cleaning the common areas used for College business only. The chauffer services are provided only during business hours to allow the president to work electronically while traveling.

THE AMOUNTS REIMBURSED WERE NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. THIS BENEFIT IS SUBJECT TO THE GUIDELINES FOR NONFIXED PAYMENTS. EMPLOYEES ARE REIMBURSED FOR BUSINESS EXPENSES THAT RELATE TO THE PRACTICE OF MEDICINE. THE TOTAL AMOUNT REIMBURSABLE IN A GIVEN FISCAL YEAR IS DETERMINED BY THE RESPECTIVE CHAIRPERSON. ALL REIMBURSEMENTS ARE SUBJECT TO APPROVAL BY THE CHAIRPERSON OR THEIR DESIGNEE. FOR AN EXPENSE TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR REIMBURSEMENT, IT MUST BE ALLOWABLE "IN ACCORDANCE WITH GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES AND ALLOWABLE TO A PRACTITIONER AS A DEDUCTIBLE COST OR EXPENSE UNDER CURRENT FEDERAL INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE GUIDELINES." DOCUMENTATION OF EXPENSES FOLLOWS IRS GUIDELINES. EXPENSES ARE NOT PROCESSED UNLESS THEY HAVE COMPLETE DOCUMENTATION. EXPENDITURES THAT ARE $25,000 OR GREATER, UNPRECEDENTED, OR UNUSUAL, WILL REQUIRE PRIOR APPROVAL FROM THE PURCHASING AND ASSET MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE.

THE MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD MEETS ANNUALLY

The University allows members of the Board of Trustees to bring their spouse to one of the two annual meetings each year. The University will pay the spouse's travel expenses and if any aggregate amount is in excess of $600 per year, it is reported on Form 1099. The University provides housing for Chief Economist, Allison Reaser. This housing is paid for directly by the University and is treated as taxable wages included in reportable compensation. The University reimburses Dr. Brower for the cost of house cleaning or landscaping expenses when his residence is used for University business.

Vanderbilt excludes the benefits from taxable income when a documented business purpose is served. First-class or charter travel - Travelers should fly via commercial airline and work to obtain the lowest fare possible. If an airline provides business class or first class seating and the length of an individual flight segment is more than four hours, the traveler may petition his/her vice Chancellor and with this written approval purchase a business or first class ticket. In cases where it is not possible to fly commercial due to scheduling commitments, and the travel is of the highest importance, travelers may request that the Chancellor approve a charter flight, after weighing the benefits of the trip against the cost of the charter. The Board of trust has approved the first class travel or charter for the Chancellor when necessitated by his schedule. Per Vanderbilt's athletics travel policy, the Vice Chancellor for University Affairs and Athletics can approve non-student travel on team charter flights, when there are extra seats, without requiring reimbursement to the university since the charter fee is not determined by the number of actual passengers. 5 officers, 2 highest compensated employees and 1 trustee were provided first-class or charter travel that was not included in taxable compensation. Travel for companion - 1 highest compensated employee was provided companion travel that was not included in taxable compensation, and 1 officer was provided companion travel that was included in taxable compensation. Health or social club dues or initiation fees - 1 officer and 1 key employee were provided health or social club dues or initiation fees that were not included in taxable compensation.

Certain individuals listed in Form 990, Schedule J, Part II, participate in nonqualified deferred compensation plans. Amounts contributed to the plans include fixed %s of annual bonus payments, and fixed dollar amounts. Contributions to the plan vest when individuals complete their contract term or continue employment to a designated date. Current year accruals of compensation associated with these plans are included in the amounts reported for such individuals in Schedule J, Part II, Column (C). The payout of these amounts in future years will be included in the amounts reported in Schedule J, Part II, Column (B)(iii) for such individuals. Amounts accrued in prior years and previously reported in Schedule J, Part II, Column (C) will be reported in Schedule J, Part II, Column (F). No payouts were made under these plans to participating individuals in 2015.

Certain individuals listed in Schedule J, Part II received variable incentive compensation based on the achievement of pre-established goals where judgement was determined either by the Board of Trust or the Chancellor. Incentive payments are shown in Schedule J, Part II, Column B(ii).

While there was no written policy to follow, the Board oversaw all provisions of expenditures and reimbursement requests submitted by the President. After submission of these requests, the Board reviewed the charges and purpose of the items to determine what would be allowable or denied. The Board worked in conjunction with the Office of Finance to ensure proper adherence to GAAP rules and regulation.

The former President (Debbie Freund) participated in a 457(f) plan for calendar year 2015. A contribution of $50,000 was made during the calendar year in accordance with the employment contract terms. Vesting and distribution occurs at the earliest of one of the following events: June 30, 2015; the date on which she separates from service involuntarily without cause, the date on which she becomes disabled, or her death. Benefits are forfeited if the President separates from service prior to June 30, 2015 for any reason other than the ones listed above. Contributions are credited to the account June 30 each year in amounts outlined in the plan document. The plan balance of $194,898 vested on June 30, 2015. There were no participants in the 457(f) plan for fiscal year June 30, 2016.

EMPLOYEES ARE REIMBURSED FOR BUSINESS EXPENSES THAT RELATE TO THE PRACTICE OF MEDICINE. THE TOTAL AMOUNT REIMBURSABLE IN A GIVEN FISCAL YEAR IS DETERMINED BY THE RESPECTIVE CHAIRPERSON. ALL REIMBURSEMENTS ARE SUBJECT TO APPROVAL BY THE CHAIRPERSON OR THEIR DESIGNEE. FOR AN EXPENSE TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR REIMBURSEMENT, IT MUST BE ALLOWABLE "IN ACCORDANCE WITH GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES AND ALLOWABLE TO A PRACTITIONER AS A DEDUCTIBLE COST OR EXPENSE UNDER CURRENT FEDERAL INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE GUIDELINES." DOCUMENTATION OF EXPENSES FOLLOWS IRS GUIDELINES. EXPENSES ARE NOT PROCESSED UNLESS THEY HAVE COMPLETE DOCUMENTATION. EXPENDITURES THAT ARE $25,000 OR GREATER, UNPRECEDENTED, OR UNUSUAL, WILL REQUIRE PRIOR APPROVAL FROM THE PURCHASING AND ASSET MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE.

HOUSING ALLOWANCES ARE GRANTED TO EMPLOYEES THAT ARE REQUIRED TO LIVE ON CAMPUS, ARE PART-TIME COACHES, OR IF INCLUDED IN TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT. SUCH ALLOWANCES ARE PROVIDED AS MONTHLY INCOME IN THE AMOUNT OF RENT AND AN ADDITIONAL 25% MARKUP TO COVER ANY TAXES. ANNUALLY, SUCH EMPLOYEES SIGN A RENTAL CONTRACT EACH JULY FOR THE UPCOMING LEASE TERM.
INFORMATION REGARDING THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE IS CONTAINED IN THE EMPLOYEES' OFFER LETTERS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: The University's written travel policy permits payment only of necessary and reasonable expenses for travel on University business. The University's policies constitute an accountable plan and are designed to comply with applicable Internal Revenue Service rules. Coach class airfare is required except in certain limited circumstances; these include medical necessity, contractual obligations, and scheduled flight segments over six hours in length, when business class fares may be used with prior approval. In rare cases, when an exception applies and no business class fare is available, a first class fare may be used, again with prior approval and documentation. Charter travel is sometimes employed for athletics teams, including coaches, when such travel is the least costly method of transportation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: Under the University's travel policy, the University does not pay the travel cost of companions, unless there is a valid University business purpose for the companion's travel. Written approval must be obtained in advance from the president, provost, or appropriate dean / vice president documenting the reason for incurring the expense. When the University uses chartered air or ground transportation, travel for companions may occasionally be included if the University incurs no additional cost.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 3 Arrangement used to establish the top management official's compensation
ExplntnTxt: The CORD (Compensation and Organizational Development) Committee of the Board of Trustees of Rice University has a written procedure in place to assure the Board of Trustees that compensation arrangements for the president and other organization officers and managers are reasonable. The procedure is designed to comply with the requirements of Section 4958 of the Internal Revenue Code and Internal Revenue Service regulations. The CORD Committee maintains a roster of disqualified persons, as defined by the IRS, for whose compensation the procedure is used. The roster is reviewed periodically but at least annually. The procedure was last discussed with the full board in March 2011. The procedure requires three elements as follows: 1) The terms of transactions are approved by the organization's governing body, or a committee thereof, whose members have no conflict of interest with respect to the arrangement. The Board of Trustees delegated authority to the CORD Committee to act on behalf of the Board in these matters at its meeting on March 25, 1999. Compensation arrangements are reviewed and approved by the CORD Committee before the effective date. Members of the CORD Committee recuse themselves from any vote in which there is a potential or actual conflict of interest. 2) The governing body or committee obtains and relies upon appropriate, comparable data before making its determination. Rice participates in the annual survey by Willis Towers Watson of select universities' executive compensation, and additional appropriate peer surveys. These reports reflect executive compensation in universities of a stature similar to that of Rice, and with which Rice competes for faculty and staff. The CORD Committee may also seek and rely on other relevant information, including compensation paid by other taxable and tax-exempt organizations for functionally comparable positions, geographic market forces, and actual written offers from similar institutions competing for services. The CORD Committee relies on this data and documents any determinations that reasonable compensation is an amount more than the range of comparable data. 3) The governing body or committee adequately documents the basis for making determinations concurrently with making decisions. Minutes documenting the deliberations of the CORD Committee are prepared contemporaneously for review and approval at its next meeting.

The College implemented a performance based incentive plan to motivate and reward persons within the investment office for achieving the Colleges long-term financial objectives. A committee appointed by the President of the College administers the incentive plan. The committee determines each participants annual incentive opportunities which vary based upon achievement of specified levels of performance for the plan year. Factors for determining incentive opportunities include benchmarking endowment returns, ranking against endowment pools of comparable organizations, net return on the endowment pool, completion of annual goals, leadership competencies and overall performance in major areas of responsibility. Timothy Jarry earned 80,368 in deferred compensation as part of the incentive plan which is included in Part II column C.

The College has established a voluntary early retirement program for tenured faculty members who have completed fifteen years of service and attained the age of sixty-two. Eligible faculty members are entitled to a percentage payout that decreases with age. In addition, eligible faculty members are able to remain enrolled in the Colleges available medical health plans. Robert Cording retired in August 2015 and received 197,220 in other reportable compensation as part of the Colleges early retirement program. There are no other amounts to be paid.

Members of the Society of Jesus take a vow of poverty. Compensation is paid directly to their order which is exempt under Section 501c3. Under Rev. Rul. 77-290 members of a religious order providing services to a Catholic organization will be considered for tax purposes to be an agent of their order provided the religious order is subject to a vow of poverty, the religious order is providing services for a Catholic organization listed in the official Catholic Directory at the discretion of their superior and the full amount of compensation is remitted to their order which is exempt from tax.

NON-TAXABLE BENEFITS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J MAY INCLUDE LIFE INSURANCE, LONG-TERM DISABILITY, EMPLOYER-PROVIDED MEDICAL INSURANCE, SECTION 125 BENEFITS, HOUSING AND TUITION. TUITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS (UP TO 100%) ARE A STANDARD BENEFIT PROVIDED BY HIGHER EDUCATION EMPLOYERS TO ELIGIBLE EMPLOYEES AND THEIR FAMILY MEMBERS. SECTION 117(D) OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SPECIFICALLY PROVIDES THAT GROSS INCOME DOES NOT INCLUDE QUALIFIED TUITION BENEFITS. THE VALUE OF THE QUALIFIED TUITION REDUCTION INCLUDED IN NONTAXABLE BENEFITS DEPENDS UPON THE NUMBER OF ELIGIBLE FAMILY MEMBERS RECEIVING THE TUITION BENEFITS DURING THE REPORTING YEAR.

Bonuses are given for exceptional performance. Sometimes they are set out at the beginning of the year in a reconfirmation letter which describes the criteria for achieving the bonus as well as the potential amount. They may also be given during the year or at annual performance review time. In either situation, consideration is given to budget limitations, the person's position, title and compensation, historical trends and market best practices.

The Personnel Committee of Quinnipiac University facilitates the evaluation process and salary review of the President and Vice Presidents of the University. The Committee meets on a regular basis at least two times each year to evaluate the performance of the President and Vice Presidents based on the success or failure of meeting their approved annual goals and objectives. Their salary adjustments based on merit are tied to this evaluation, comparative salary data from similar institutions and recommendations of the President or, in the case of the President, the Committee. The Committee has authority as delegated to it by the full Board of Trustees to execute and amend the contracts for the President and Vice Presidents of the University.

Quinnipiac University Online is administered by Quinnipiac University employees. The Personnel Committee of Quinnipiac University facilitates the evaluation process and salary review of the President and Vice Presidents of the University. The Committee meets on a regular basis at least two times each year to evaluate the performance of the President and Vice Presidents based on the success or failure of meeting their approved annual goals and objectives. Their salary adjustments based on merit are tied to this evaluation, comparative salary data from similar institutions and recommendations of the President or, in the case of the President, the Committee. The Committee has authority as delegated to it by the full Board of Trustees to execute and amend the contracts for the President and Vice Presidents of the University.

ExplntnTxt: The President is the only employee eligible for first class and spousal/companion travel. Other executives may be approved based on medical documentation only. Rensselaer's President is allowed to use first class travel on Rensselaer business in accordance with the terms of her employment agreement, which was approved by independent members of the Compensation and Personnel Development Committee. The President's expenses are subject to review by the Board of Trustees, including any amounts for spousal or companion travel. The Board has oversight of strategic issues for facilities management, which include but are not limited to capital improvements and other costs for Rensselaer's presidential residence. The Board of Rensselaer also oversees the review and audit of expenses of the President relating to the presidential residence and personal services associated with the upkeep of the residence. Such review occurs under the Board's oversight on an at least annual basis.

ExplntnTxt: Eligible executives participate in a program that provides for supplemental retirement benefits. The payment of benefits under the program, if any, is entirely dependent upon the facts and circumstances under which the executive terminates employment with the organization. Benefits under the program are unfunded and non-vested. Due to the substantial risk of forfeiture provision, there is no guarantee that these executives will ever receive any benefit under the program. Any amount ultimately paid under the program to the executive is reported as compensation on Form 990, Schedule J, Part II, Column B in the year paid. ExplntnTxt: Board Members, Officers, Key Employees and Highest Compensated Employees who are employed by the CSM Organizations and are medical doctors are eligible to receive a percentage of the revenue generated from patients they served, based on established guidelines. Officers and Key Employees participate in a management incentive place, whereby certain financial triggers of the CSM System as approved by the Board must be met before any eligible employee may receive payment of the incentive. Once the trigger is met, the incentive is measured based on various established goals, including operating margin, patient satisfaction, quality and productivity.

First Class Travel: Pursuant to a written policy and appropriate approval, first class travel is permitted to certain officers and key employees for business purposes. Travel for business purposes is not included in taxable wages. One officer listed in Form 990, Part VII flew first class during calendar year 2015. Travel for companions: Pursuant to a written policy, certain officers and key employees' spouses are permitted to travel on occasion when necessary for business purpose. Travel for business purpose is not included in taxable wages. Two officers listed in form 990, Part VII were provided with companion travel for business purposes during calendar year 2015. Gross-up payment: Pursuant to California Civil code, Pepperdine University provides gross-up to employees that provide late substantiation of expenses under accountable plan rules for ordinary and necessary business expenses. As part of the ministerial housing program, Pepperdine provided additional compensation to participants for wage withholding in an amount equal to the employer's share of the participants' self-employment tax. The individuals listed in Form 990, Part VII were provided with gross-up payments during calendar year 2015 include 1 key employee. Housing: included in non-taxable benefits of employees who are ministers is the value of housing allowance provided by Pepperdine University to ministers. The provision of ministerial housing is subject to executive approval. The individuals listed in Form 990, Part VII who were provided with ministerial housing during calendar year 2015 include 4 officers and 4 key employees. Housing is provided for 3 officers as a condition of employment for the convenience of the employer and is not included in taxable wages. Social clubs: Two of the listed individuals received reimbursements for expenditures associated with social club memberships. All expenditures are for business purposes and are approved pursuant to the University's reimbursement policies. Personal service: One officer is provided certain house cleaning services in connection with his occupancy of on-campus housing. The provision of such services is not included as taxable wages

PEPPERDINE UNIVERSITY HAS AN INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN KEY EXECUTIVES. UNDER THE PLAN, UPON ACHIEVEMENT OF CERTAIN EXPECTATIONS AND GOALS AND AT THE DISCRETION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS, THE PARTICIPANT WILL RECEIVE A UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTION TO THE PLAN FOR THAT PLAN YEAR. UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PLAN BECOME GRADUALLY VESTED BEGINNING WITH THE LAST DAY OF THE 3RD PLAN YEAR FOLLOWING THE CONTRIBUTION AND VEST 100% AT THE COMPLETION OF THE 7TH PLAN YEAR FOLLOWING THE AWARD. IF THE EMPLOYEE HAS ATTAINED AGE 62, THE VESTING SCHEDULE IS ACCELERATED SUCH THAT THE EMPLOYEE IS FULLY VESTED BY AGE 65. First-class travel Dartmouth travel policy allows for first or business class air travel for business purposes in limited circumstances. Consistent with this policy, on infrequent occasions senior officers flew first class with the President's approval. The lack of a major commercial airport within 80 miles of Dartmouth requires use of charter air travel to fulfill the business travel requirements of the President. For this reason, the President and certain senior officers had access for business purposes to charter flight service, the cost of which was fully defrayed by private donations designated for this purpose. Travel for companions The President's wife, who is also an employee of Dartmouth, traveled with him for business purposes including participating in alumni events and meetings with key constituent donors on Dartmouth's behalf. Tax indemnification and gross-up payments During calendar 2015, Dartmouth elected to pay the tax obligations that arose from certain compensation transactions for one individual. These payments were treated as taxable compensation. Housing Allowance or residence for personal use Dartmouth provided housing for the President and Provost. These arrangements were for Dartmouth's convenience and a condition of employment and therefore were not taxable to the individuals. Personal Services Dartmouth provided housekeeping services for cleaning and maintaining the President's house. The value of services provided for personal living space was recognized as imputed income to the President.

Participate in or receive payments from Nonqualified Retirement Plans Dartmouth provided the President with a nonqualified 457(f) supplemental retirement plan. The Plan provided for annual credits to the plan subject to vesting requirements based on continuation of employment through set dates. The President received $80,000, and accrued $160,000 relative to the Plan during the calendar year 2015. $40,000 of the deferred compensation received had been reported in prior years, as reflected in Column F.

Robert Lasher, Senior Vice President for Advancement, received a performance bonus of $25,000 during calendar year 2015. Pamela Peedin, Chief Investment Officer, received incentive compensation of $859,386 during calendar year 2015. Michael Sullivan, Managing Director in the Investment Office, received incentive compensation of $349,639 during calendar year 2015.

BENEFITS PROVIDED - WELLESLEY COLLEGE'S POLICY IS THAT THE COLLEGE WILL NOT PAY FOR - OR REIMBURSE - TRAVEL, MEALS, AND EXPENSES OF THE SPOUSE/PARTNER OF AN EMPLOYEE WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PRESIDENT. SPECIFICALLY, WHILE PERFORMING HER OFFICIAL DUTIES IN THE AREAS OF DEVELOPMENT, ALUMNAE RELATIONS, AND OTHER BUSINESS OF THE COLLEGE, THE PRESIDENT MAY BE ACCOMPANIED BY HER SPOUSE, WHO IS EXPECTED TO MAKE AN IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTION TO ACHIEVING THE PURPOSES OF THE TRAVEL OR EVENTS. IN THOSE CASES, THE COLLEGE'S POLICY IS TO AUTHORIZE THE PAYMENT OF ALL TRAVEL AND RELATED EXPENSES OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE. THE COLLEGE PROVIDES HOUSING TO CERTAIN EMPLOYEES AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE AND BENEFIT OF THE COLLEGE. THE HOUSING REQUIREMENT AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT IS DOCUMENTED IN THE EMPLOYEES' FILES. THE COLLEGE WILL NOT PAY FOR PERSONAL SERVICES WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE. BECAUSE THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE IS USED EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS, HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES ARE PROVIDED FOR THE GENERAL SPACE. A CHEF WILL BE AT THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE TO PROVIDE MEALS FOR BUSINESS PURPOSE FUNCTIONS.

Explanation: James Conwell, President, received club dues and spouse travel reimbursement, which are grossed for tax purposes. He also received a housing allowance, which is reported in Schedule J, Part II and is reported as taxable on the W-2.

- Travel for Companions - The College pays for expenses for the President's spouse's travel as covered per contract with valid business reason. - Tax indemnification and gross-up payments - President's tuition remission benefits were grossed up which is allowable by his employment contract. - Housing allowance or residence for personal use - The College provides housing to the president as a condition of employment. - Health or social club dues - The College pays dues for the California Club for the sole purpose of conducting college business; no personal social activities are allowed. The value of the employer provided housing has been determined to meet the criteria of Sec 119 and is therefore reported as a non-taxable benefit. Because no personal social activities are conducted, the California Club dues are not included in taxable compensation.

PARTICIPATION IN A NON-QUALIFIED PLAN: A PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT TO BENEFITS WILL VEST ON THE PARTICIPANT'S VESTING DATE PROVIDED THE PARTICIPANT HAS REMAINED IN CONTINUOUS EMPLOYMENT IN THE SAME POSITION WHILE PARTICIPATING IN THIS PLAN. A PARTICIPANT WILL HAVE ONLY ONE VESTING DATE FOR ALL ELECTIVE DEFERRALS AND OTHER PLAN CONTRIBUTIONS MADE ON THE PARTICIPANT'S BEHALF DURING ALL PLAN YEARS. A PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT TO BENEFITS WILL ALSO VEST (A) IF THE PARTICIPANT DIES WHILE STILL EMPLOYED BY THE EMPLOYER; (B) IF THE PARTICIPANT'S EMPLOYMENT TERMINATES DUE TO TOTAL DISABILITY; OR (C) IF THE EMPLOYER TERMINATES THE PARTICIPANT'S EMPLOYMENT FOR ANY REASON OTHER THAN FOR CAUSE. ANY PORTION OF THE PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT TO BENEFITS THAT IS NOT VESTED WHEN THE PARTICIPANT'S EMPLOYMENT WITH THE EMPLOYER TERMINATES, INCLUDING ELECTIVE DEFERRALS, WILL BE FORFEITED. THE EMPLOYER WILL DISTRIBUTE A PARTICIPANT'S BENEFITS UNDER THE PLAN AS SOON AS PRACTICABLE AFTER THE PARTICIPANT'S ENTITLEMENT BECOMES VESTED. ExplntnTxt: COMPENSATION REPORTED IN PRIOR FORM 990: COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THAT THE COMPENSATION IS EARNED BY OR AWARDED TO AN INDIVIDUAL, EVEN IF THE COMPENSATION IS NOT PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL, IS NOT FULLY VESTED, OR IS SUBJECT TO SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE. IF COMPENSATION IS EARNED OR AWARDED IN ONE YEAR BUT PAID IN A LATER YEAR, THEN THE COMPENSATION IS REPORTED A SECOND TIME ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS VESTED OR PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL.

DETAIL OF ADDITIONAL BENEFITS PROVIDED FIRST CLASS TRAVEL IN GENERAL, IT IS SWARTHMORE COLLEGE'S (THE "COLLEGE") POLICY THAT FIRST CLASS TRAVEL IS NOT AUTHORIZED FOR COLLEGE EMPLOYEES TRAVELING ON COLLEGE BUSINESS. HOWEVER, IN RECOGNITION THAT THE PRESIDENT TYPICALLY WORKS DURING FLIGHTS, ATTENDS DIRECTLY TO BUSINESS UPON ARRIVAL, AND CANNOT SCHEDULE IN TIME FOR ADEQUATE REST, THE BOARD OF MANAGERS HAS APPROVED THE USE OF FIRST CLASS TRAVEL FOR THE PRESIDENT ON DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL FLIGHTS OVER THREE HOURS IN LENGTH. THIS POLICY EXTENDS TO THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE WHEN HE OR SHE ACCOMPANIES THE PRESIDENT ON BUSINESS TRAVEL. FOR ALL OTHER EMPLOYEES (FACULTY AND STAFF), FIRST CLASS TRAVEL MUST BE PRE-APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT OR HIS/HER DESIGNATE. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS IN CERTAIN AUTHORIZED CIRCUMSTANCES THE COLLEGE WILL PAY, OR WILL REIMBURSE, FOR THE TRAVEL, MEALS AND EXPENSES OF THE SPOUSE/PARTNER OF AN EMPLOYEE UNDER THE COLLEGE'S ACCOUNTABLE PLAN. REIMBURSEMENTS ARE CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME TO THE EMPLOYEE UNLESS THE COMPANION TRAVEL IS: 1) FOR A BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE, 2) DIRECTLY BENEFITS THE COLLEGE, AND 3) IS PROPERLY DOCUMENTED AND APPROVED. ANY SPOUSE/PARTNER TRAVEL OTHER THAN THE PRESIDENT MUST BE APPROVED, IN ADVANCE, BY THE PRESIDENT OR HIS/HER DESIGNATE. (1) AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT AND FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY, PRESIDENT ROBERT BROWN AND PROVOST JEAN MORRISON WERE BOTH REQUIRED TO LIVE IN UNIVERSITY RESIDENCES. AMOUNTS REPORTED IN COLUMN D INCLUDE, IN ADDITION TO OTHER NON-TAXABLE BENEFITS, THE ESTIMATED FAIR MARKET RENTAL VALUE OF THE UNIVERSITY-PROVIDED RESIDENCE, BASED UPON AN INDEPENDENT OPINION OF VALUE AND WITHOUT ANY ALLOCATION OR REDUCTION FOR UNIVERSITY USE OF THE PREMISES, FOR PRESIDENT BROWN ($248,420) AND PROVOST MORRISON ($138,577). FORMER PROVOST DAVID CAMPBELL WAS PROVIDED A TAXABLE HOUSING ALLOWANCE OF $24,000 AS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT; THIS AMOUNT IS INCLUDED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B(III) AS OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION. (2) FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL: IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL AND BUSINESS EXPENSE GUIDELINES, ALL EMPLOYEES ARE REIMBURSED FOR ECONOMY AIRFARE. EXCEPTIONS FOR TRAVEL INVOLVING AN EXTENDED PERIOD OF TIME ARE PERMITTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TERMS OF THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL AND BUSINESS EXPENSE GUIDELINES. THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT ALLOWS FOR FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL. TRAVEL FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES, INCLUDING FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL, IS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE WAGES. THE PRESIDENT IS THE ONLY INDIVIDUAL REPORTED ON FORM 990, PART VII WHO TRAVELED FIRST-CLASS DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2015. (3) TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL AND BUSINESS EXPENSE GUIDELINES, BOSTON UNIVERSITY ALLOWS COMPANION TRAVEL FOR BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSES. ALL SUCH CASES REQUIRE THE PRIOR WRITTEN APPROVAL OF AN AUTHORIZED SENIOR EXECUTIVE. THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT ALLOWS FOR SPOUSAL TRAVEL. COMPANION TRAVEL FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES IS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE WAGES. THE PRESIDENT IS THE ONLY INDIVIDUAL REPORTED ON FORM 990, PART VII WHO UTILIZED COMPANION TRAVEL DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2015. (4) TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS: FROM TIME TO TIME, BOSTON UNIVERSITY MAY PROVIDE CERTAIN PAYMENTS THAT HAVE BEEN GROSSED-UP FOR TAX PURPOSES. ALL SUCH CASES INVOLVING THE UNIVERSITY'S SENIOR EXECUTIVES REQUIRE THE APPROVAL OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. FOR CALENDAR YEAR 2015, NO INDIVIDUAL REPORTED ON FORM 990, PART VII RECEIVED THIS BENEFIT.

(1) UNDER A SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN, ON AUGUST 1 OF EACH OF THE FIVE CALENDAR YEARS FROM 2011 THROUGH 2015 PRESIDENT BROWN RECEIVED A CREDIT EQUAL TO 30% OF HIS BASE SALARY FOR THE PRECEDING 12-MONTH PERIOD. EACH OF THESE CREDITS WAS SUBJECT TO THE PERFORMANCE OF FUTURE SERVICES AND OTHER CONDITIONS AS WELL AS A SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE UNTIL PRESIDENT BROWNS RIGHTS IN THE PLAN BECAME VESTED ON AUGUST 1, 2015. UPON VESTING, SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT PLAN COMPENSATION OF $1,222,771 (REPRESENTING THE TOTAL OF THE FIVE AMOUNTS CREDITED, WITHOUT INTEREST) WAS DISTRIBUTED TO PRESIDENT BROWN IN CALENDAR YEAR 2015 AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B(III) AS OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION. THE PORTION OF THE AMOUNT DISTRIBUTED WHICH WAS PREVIOUSLY REPORTED AS RETIREMENT AND OTHER DEFERRED COMPENSATION ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN C OF PRIOR FORMS 990 IS $958,899. THIS AMOUNT IS THEREFORE REPORTED ON THIS YEARS SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN F. UNDER THE SAME SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT PLAN, ON AUGUST 1, 2016, PRESIDENT BROWN WAS TO BECOME ENTITLED TO RECEIVE AN AMOUNT EQUAL TO 30% OF HIS BASE SALARY FOR THE PRECEDING 12-MONTH PERIOD. PRESIDENT BROWNS RIGHT TO SUCH PAYMENT WAS SUBJECT TO THE PERFORMANCE OF FUTURE SERVICES AND OTHER CONDITIONS AS WELL AS A SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE UNTIL THAT DATE. ACCORDINGLY, SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT PLAN COMPENSATION OF $113,125 WAS ACCRUED FOR PRESIDENT BROWN IN CALENDAR YEAR 2015 AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN C AS RETIREMENT AND OTHER DEFERRED COMPENSATION. (2) AMOUNTS REPORTED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B(III) AS OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION ALSO INCLUDE CONTRIBUTIONS MADE BY THE UNIVERSITY IN CALENDAR YEAR 2015 TO AN IRC SECTION 457(B) SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN TO PROVIDE FUTURE RETIREMENT BENEFITS TO PRESIDENT BROWN AND TODD KLIPP.

DETAIL OF ADDITIONAL BENEFITS PROVIDED FIRST CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL THE MODE OF AIR TRAVEL UTILIZED BY UNIVERSITY EMPLOYEES IS EXPECTED TO BE THE LEAST COSTLY OPTION, CONSISTENT WITH THE ITINERARY AND PARTICULAR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE INVOLVED. ON FEDERALLY FUNDED PROJECTS, COMPLIANCE WITH THE FLY AMERICA ACT TAKES PRECEDENCE OVER CHOOSING A LESS EXPENSIVE FOREIGN CARRIER. IN CERTAIN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES, CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS MAY TRAVEL FIRST CLASS. ANY FIRST CLASS EXCEPTIONS TO THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICY ARE SUBJECT TO APPROPRIATE REVIEW AND APPROVAL. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS TRAVEL EXPENSES OF A SPOUSE (OR DEPENDENT) MAY BE PROVIDED BY THE UNIVERSITY AS A REGULAR BUSINESS EXPENSE ONLY IF THE TRAVEL SERVES A "BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE" OF THE UNIVERSITY. FURTHER, TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR SPOUSES AND DEPENDENTS ARE ALLOWABLE DURING THE INTERVIEW PROCESS PRIOR TO AN EMPLOYMENT OFFER, SINCE EMPLOYMENT IS CONSIDERED A FAMILY DECISION. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS THE UNIVERSITY MAY PROVIDE TAX GROSS-UP PAYMENTS UNDER CERTAIN CIRCUMSTANCES WITH APPROPRIATE APPROVAL. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT GENERALLY PROVIDE TAX INDEMNIFICATIONS. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE/HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES/PERSONAL SERVICES AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN A HOME ON THE UNIVERSITY'S CAMPUS WHICH IS FURNISHED AND MAINTAINED AT THE UNIVERSITY'S EXPENSE. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PROVIDES A HEALTH/SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIP, TO BE USED BY THE PRESIDENT IN CONNECTION WITH HER DUTIES. THE PRESIDENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY PERSONAL USE OF THE CLUB MEMBERSHIP, HOUSEHOLD STAFF OR OTHER PERSONAL EXPENSES INCURRED. --------------------

SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN PARTICIPATION THE TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA (THE "UNIVERSITY") MAINTAINS A SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN ("SERP") DESIGNED FOR SENIOR ADMINISTRATORS AND DEANS OF THE UNIVERSITY AS DESIGNATED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES WHO HAVE MADE THE 5% EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTION TO THE UNIVERSITY'S 403(B) PLAN, HAVE UNIVERSITY COMPENSATION OVER CERTAIN IRS PROSCRIBED THRESHOLDS, AND ARE ACTIVELY EMPLOYED BY THE UNIVERSITY WHEN THE CONTRIBUTION IS MADE. VESTING IN THE SERP OCCURS AFTER EACH THREE YEARS OF PARTICIPATION AND UPON THE OCCURRENCE OF CERTAIN EVENTS (ATTAINMENT OF AGE 65, DEATH, DISABILITY, OR INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION WITHOUT "CAUSE"). CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THOSE WHO HAVE REACHED AGE 65 WILL BE FULLY VESTED WHEN MADE. UPON REACHING A VESTING DATE, PARTICIPANTS WILL AUTOMATICALLY RECEIVE A "PARTIAL" DISTRIBUTION WHICH WILL BE WITHHELD TO SATISFY THE TAX CONSEQUENCES OF VESTING. THE BALANCE OF VESTED SERP ACCOUNT WILL REMAIN IN THE PLAN AND WILL BE DISTRIBUTED (PLUS OR MINUS INVESTMENT EARNINGS/LOSSES) UPON TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT. PARTICIPANTS WHO VOLUNTARILY TERMINATE BEFORE VESTING WILL FORFEIT THE BALANCE IN THEIR ACCOUNTS. VESTING IN THE SERP OCCURS AFTER EACH THREE YEARS OF PARTICIPATION AND UPON THE OCCURRENCE OF CERTAIN EVENTS (ATTAINMENT OF AGE 65, DEATH, DISABILITY, OR INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION WITHOUT "CAUSE"). CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THOSE WHO HAVE REACHED AGE 65 WILL BE FULLY VESTED WHEN MADE. The President is required to maintain a personal residence on campus as a condition of employment for the convenience of the employer. Certain personal services are provided to maintain this residence. Occasional personal services provided to the President are considered personal expenses and added to the President's taxable compensation including the value of the related tax liability. In accordance with Amherst Travel Policy, first class travel is permitted for business purposes in some circumstances. Consistent with this policy, on occasion, the President and certain staff have traveled first class. In addition, the President and other employees have traveled by charter service per the terms of a restricted gift that is specifically designated for certain travel for locations that lack direct and frequent flights. These expenses are reviewed and monitored by personnel in the Chief Financial Officer's Office. In accordance with a key employee's employment agreement, a dependent's taxable grant was added to the employee's taxable compensation including the value of the related tax liability.

The College participated in an annual survey of comparable institutions which compared historic salaries and designated benefits for the chief executive. The Board of Trustees delegated to an ad hoc Committee on Compensation, consisting of independent trustees, authority to determine the compensation of the President in accordance with the Compensation Policy for Designated Individuals approved by the Board in May 2012. The Committee on Compensation reviewed the relevant survey information, conducted an annual evaluation of the President, determined the President's compensation and contemporaneously documented its decision. The Committee on Compensation shared its findings and compensation decision with the Board of Trustees.

The College requires that the President, the VP for Academic Affairs and the VP for Communications and Development reside on campus as a condition of their employment; therefore, College owned housing is provided for them. In addition, the College pays for reasonable costs of housekeeping to maintain the president's residence. First class and business class air travel is allowed for members of senior staff only when the travel is ten hours or more. Other services provided to the president include travel for her spouse when it has been determined that his travel fulfills a bona fide business purpose for the College and payment for membership in one club in Manhattan, such as the University Club, for the purpose of meeting with College constituents, sponsoring College events and otherwise conducting College business. Because these benefits are nontaxable, they are not included in the employees' Form W-2. However, they are included in Part II, column D.
See schedule O disclosure for Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15.

The School on infrequent occasions provides non-coach (generally business-class, although first-class may be used if business-class is unavailable) travel for its officers for travel to international destinations, in accordance with the School's policy. Such travel is in direct support of the School's educational and performance programs (such as, for example, an international performance tour of the student orchestra). Also, on occasion the School provides transportation for the spouse of the President to attend, on behalf of the School, functions or other events together with the President in direct support and furtherance of the School's mission. In accordance with the terms of his employment, the President has non-exclusive access to use an apartment within the School's residence facility. However, his actual use of the apartment is extremely infrequent and when it does occur, its primarily for business purposes (for example, when school events require his presence and weather conditions do not permit safe travel). The apartment is used primarily to house visiting teachers and artists engaged to teach at the School and is occupied for most of the year for this purpose.

An employment contract is executed between the School and its President, the terms of which are subject to review by the Board of Trustees. At the end of the contract's term, when deciding the terms under which the contract may be renewed or extended, the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees, with the assistance of an outside compensation expert, conducts research among peer institutions and documents the findings and decisions reached. The compensation of officers and other key employees is reviewed annually by the Compensation Committee prior to the start of each fiscal year, and questions, objections, and the resolution of each is documented.

Sr. Managing Directors Christopher Mossey and Mark Murtagh were paid bonuses for the calendar year 2015, which are reported on the Form 990, Schedule J, part II, Column (b)(ii). President Joseph Polisi, who has served as President of the School since 1984, received payment in calendar year 2015 of approximately $1.2 million of deferred compensation earned over a period of four prior fiscal years (2011-12 through 2014-15), including interest thereon. The payment is reported on the Form 990, Schedule J, Part II, Column B(iii) and Column F.

THE UNIVERSITY FUNDS A PARTIAL SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIP IN THE NAME OF AN OFFICER. THE MEMBERSHIP IS USED FOR UNIVERSITY EVENTS AND THE ENTERTAINMENT OF PROSPECTIVE DONORS AND CONTRIBUTORS. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ON CAMPUS HOUSING TO ITS PRESIDENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE ESTIMATED RENT IS INCLUDED AS NON-TAXABLE BENEFIT IN COLUMN (D).

COMPENSATION FOR THE UNIVERSITY'S PRESIDENT/CEO IS DETERMINED THROUGH AN EXTENSIVE REVIEW OF THE JOB RESPONSIBILITIES AND EXPECTATIONS OUTLINED BY THE BOARD. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE THEN PERFORMS A REVIEW OF EXTERNAL MARKET AND INDUSTRY SURVEY AND STUDY DATA. CONSIDERATION OF ALL ADDITIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES ARE DETAILED OUT IN SPECIFIC LANGUAGE IN AN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT APPROVED BY OUR LEGAL COUNSEL. FINAL SALARY RANGES ARE THEN DETERMINED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. COMPENSATION IS DETERMINED BY THE EVALUATION OF THE JOB DESCRIPTION AGAINST EXTERNAL MARKET DATA AVAILABLE AS WELL AS THE REVIEW OF OUR INTERNAL EMPLOYEE DATA. CONSIDERATION OF ADDITIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES AND OTHER FACTORS MAY ALSO CONTRIBUTE IN DETERMINING COMPENSATION. THE DELIBERATION AND DECISION ARE CONTEMPORANEOUSLY DOCUMENTED.
BONUSES ARE PAID TO SENIOR STAFF MEMBERS BASED IN PART ON ACHIEVING BUDGETED REVENUE GOALS.

BONUSES ARE PAID TO SENIOR STAFF MEMBERS BASED IN PART ON ACHIEVING THE TRANSFER TO THE TRUSTEE RESERVES. SENIOR STAFF MEMBERS HAVE PERFORMANCE MEASURES FOR MANAGING THE UNIVERSITY TO MAINTAIN A BALANCED BUDGET.

THERE ARE QUANTITATIVE MEASURES THAT ARE APPLIED IN DETERMINING BONUSES TO SENIOR STAFF MEMBERS. THE PRESIDENT AND THE BOARD HAVE DISCRETION TO ADJUST THE PAYMENTS FOR UNUSUAL CIRCUMSTANCES. IN ALL CASES, THESE PAYMENTS ARE REVIEWED WITH AND APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES.

THE FOLLOWING INDIVIDUALS LISTED ON FORM 990, PART VII RECEIVED COMPENSATION THAT WAS PAID PURSUANT TO AN INITIAL CONTRACT WITH THE UNIVERSITY: - LAURA NIESEN DE ABRUNA, PROVOST AND VICE PRESIDENT - MICHAEL LAROBINA, GENERAL COUNSEL

COMPENSATION FOR THE UNIVERSITY'S OTHER OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES IS ORIGINALLY DETERMINED BASED ON EXTERNAL MARKET AND INDUSTRY SURVEY AS WELL AS THE REVIEW OF OUR INTERNAL EMPLOYEE DATA. ANY ADDITIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES ARE ALSO CONSIDERED. THE DATA IS REVIEWED BY A COMMITTEE AUTHORIZED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. By the nature of the position, the CEO is required to fulfill several obligations/commitments which may result in travelling first-class and/or charter to accommodate required appointments. Further his spouse may accompany him as well as dictated by her required presence for an event. The CEO has available to him a discretionary fund (budgeted each year) for assisting individuals and/or projects in need of support. Further, the CEO is required to reside in college-owned housing for the purpose of being a presence on campus and for entertainment purposes. As the result of living in a college-owned residence, the College provides, as with all campus buildings, light housekeeping. The position of CEO also requires membership in certain social/academic organizations and therefore, the college provides the dues/fees associated with that membership. From time to time the College utilizes the College President's personal residence for College events and housing of College guests.

The Prudential Committee (executive committee) of the Board of Trustees approves the CEO's annual salary. The Treasurer's Office secures salary information supplied by the Chronicle of Higher Education, IRS Form 990 of other organizations, compensation consultants and written contract. This information is then provided to the Prudential Committee for their review and evaluation.
Depending on the levels of gift revenue, bonuses were paid.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part I, Line 1a: Relevant information in regards to selections on 1a.

ExplntnTxt: Housing Allowance or Residence for Personal Use The University requires the President to reside in the Turner Fleming House, located on campus, for the convenience of the University, as part of his employment contract with the University. The Turner Fleming House is used by the President for personal residence, hosting various meetings and business-related social events and other University functions. The University provides housekeeping, grounds keeping, and maintenance service consistent with other University buildings. The valuation for personal usage of the Turner Fleming House, as reported in housing allowance on Schedule J, Part II, Column (d), nontaxable benefits, includes the estimated fair market rental value, utilities, housekeeping, and grounds keeping services. Tax Indemnification And Gross-Up Payments The University reimburses the president for income tax obligations related to university social and club dues. These gross-up payments are treated as taxable compensation and reported on IRS Form W-2. Health or Social Club Dues Or Initiation Fees The University provides a country club membership and other social club memberships for the President of the University. These memberships are used primarily for hosting guests during fundraising meetings and other business related meetings. University-provided memberships are treated as taxable compensation and reported on IRS Form W-2. Personal Services The University provides housekeeping and ground sevices for the President's home. The value of these services is included in the President's housing allowance on Schedule J, Part II, Column (d), nontaxable benefits.

Voluntary Separation Agreement Jim Hunt received an additional amount of $358,250 on his final payment in May 2015. Incentive payment for voluntary retirement (VIRP) Richard Roemer received an amount of $119,100 in 2015.
supplement nonqualified retirement plan President Burger participated in a 457(f) plan - For calendar year 2015 University Contributions were $32,259 and personal contributions were $220,194.

The President is required by contract to reside on campus. The President's residence is also used for various University and Board of Trustee functions. The University provides for premises housekeeping and maintenance. University policy allows for very limited travel expenses for companions. All presidential travel and other expenses are reviewed yearly by the Audit Committee of the Board of Trustees.

Employment of the President is initiated by the Board of Trustees. The Evaluation Committee of the Board reviews the President's performance and compensation and reports to the full Board. The Committee recommends any adjustment to the President's compensation through a resolution that the full Board discusses and votes on. All Board Resolutions are public information and are posted on the University's web page.
THE PRESIDENT OF PHILANDER SMITH COLLEGE RECEIVED $31,200 IN HOUSING ALLOWANCE.

The President of the College is permitted certain perquisites by virtue of his position at the College. By contract, the President is entitled to a housing allowance and reimbursement for social club dues incurred in the course of conducting College business. The President's housing allowance is a taxable benefit and is included in the President's "other reportable compensation" column (b)(iii) in Schedule J. The President uses the social club solely in a business capacity and therefore, this is a non-taxable fringe benefit. The compensation of the President is approved by the Board of Trustees.

The President of the College is a participant in a Section 457(f) and 457(b) plan and received employer funded contributions in the amount of $108,000 for 2015. A former key employee received $104,047 in compensation as part of the severance package.

Form 990, Schedule J, Part I Line 1 - The President of the College is provided a home in close proximity to the campus as a condition of his employment. The value of the residence provided to the President on campus has not been assigned a fair market value and is not included in Schedule J, Part II, Column (d). As required, the College provides cleaning and maintenance services for the employer provided housing. The college occasionally requires the travel, at various business functions, of the President's spouse (who is also a part-time employee of the College, but whose compensation did not exceed $10,000 and therefore is not required to be disclosed on Schedule L) and the VP for Advancement's spouse. Travel depends on the nature of the function and the duties of the spouses are determined in advance and approved. In such instances full substantiation of the expenses is also required. Finally, the College pays the social club membership dues of the President and the Vice President for Advancement so that they may host donors and other business guests of the College at activities designed to benefit the College. To the extent that these individuals incur any personal expenses related to their social club usage, they are required to reimburse the College. All business expenditures must be substantiated to be excluded from their wages.

FIRST-CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL: The president is the only position reported in the Form 990 for which the university paid or reimbursed business or first-class travel. The university did not utilize chartered flights for air travel. Extensive travel is required of the position of president and he is encouraged by the Board of Trustees to travel business or first class on flights of two hours or more. This provision is made for several reasons: 1) business or first-class travel allows for the most flexibility to accommodate a travel schedule that must frequently be altered, often at the last minute to accommodate donors' schedules, add critical meetings, or to take advantage of other strategic opportunities for the university; 2) circumstances sometimes call for the president to return to campus without notice, or to remain on campus when a trip was planned, and first or business-class travel best accommodates these changing conditions; and 3) the Board of Trustees wishes the president to be at his best performance representing and seeking funding for the university during often grueling travel itineraries for meetings frequently critical to the institution's well-being. This accommodation was not treated as taxable compensation. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: The president is required to live on campus in the university-owned president's residence where he regularly holds university events. Because the president accepts this requirement as a condition of employment, the residence is on university premises, and it is provided for the convenience of the university, under IRS rules it is not considered a taxable benefit to the president. As required by IRS Form 990, the value of the portion of the residence used by the president for personal living quarters has been estimated and is included in the amounts reported on Form 990, Schedule J, Part II, Column (D).

RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY PERIODICALLY STAYS OVERNIGHT IN UNIVERSITY OWNED FACILITIES. SOCIAL CLUB DUES THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FOR THE ANNUAL COST OF MEMBERSHIP DUES IN TWO SOCIAL CLUBS FOR ITS PRESIDENT, LOCAL TO CAMPUS. THE FULL AMOUNT OF DUES PAID IS REPORTED ANNUALLY ON THE PRESIDENT'S FORM W-2 ANNUAL WAGE AND TAX STATEMENT AS A TAXABLE FRINGE BENEFIT PURSUANT TO INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 274(A)(3), AND HAS BEEN DISCLOSED IN COLUMN B (III) OF SCHEDULE J. THE USE OF THE CLUBS IS PRIMARILY FOR THE PURPOSES OF BUSINESS MEETINGS AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT FURTHERING THE INTERESTS OF THE UNIVERSITY. USE OF THE CLUBS IS DOCUMENTED AND ANY COSTS FOR PERSONAL MEALS OR USE ARE PAID BY THE PRESIDENT PERSONALLY WHEN INCURRED.

JOHN BOWEN AND THOMAS DWYER PARTICIPATE IN A SUPPLEMENTAL EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT PLAN (SERP), WHICH WAS ESTABLISHED UNDER SECTION 457(F) OF THE IRC. THE SERP WAS ESTABLISHED AND APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES IN 2006 TO REWARD PERFORMANCE, LOYALTY, AND CONTINUOUS SERVICE OF SELECTED EXECUTIVES TO AGE 65. ONLY EXECUTIVES SPECIFICALLY DESIGNATED BY THE BOARD QUALIFY FOR PARTICIPATION, THEY MUST REMAIN EMPLOYED BY THE INSTITUTION THROUGH AGE 65 AND THE BENEFIT SUPPLEMENTS OTHER INSTITUTIONAL RETIREMENT PLANS SUCH THAT THE RECIPIENT WILL RECEIVE TOTAL RETIREMENT INCOME EQUAL TO 75% OF FINAL COMPENSATION.

CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN PART VII, SECTION A, LINE 1(A), WERE PAID BONUSES, SEE SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN A AND B (II), FOR THE SUCCESSFUL IMPLEMENTATION OF PROGRAMS IN SUPPORT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S COMMITMENT TO STUDENT COOPERATIVE LEARNING EXPERIENCES.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a: First-Class Travel: First-class travel is allowed only for employees that have a special need or are traveling with a potential donor of the University. This benefit is nontaxable to the employee receiving the benefit. No such benefit was paid in the tax year ending june 30,2016. Tax Indemnification and Gross-Up Payments: The President received a tax gross-up payment for an auto lease, which is included in compensation reported on Schedule J, Part II, Column (b)(i). Discretionary Spending Account: When external funds are generated (usually from a speaking engagement) by a Dean or Faculty member, a discretionary fund is created for the individual to help supplement their continuing education requirements or research projects. This benefit is nontaxable to the employee receiving the benefit. No such benefit was paid in the tax year ending june 30,2016. Health Club or Social Club Dues: There are contract arrangements with certain individuals that pay for the health costs which are included as compensation reported on Form W-2. In addition, the University will pay for social club dues for executive members to congregate and promote the university's mission while developing relationships that can further develop contributions to the university. Personal Services: The University provides additional home health care medical services for the President and his wife to the extent such services are not covered by other insurance maintained by the President, his wife, or the University, and is not subject to reimbursement from other sources. These benefits have been authorized and approved by the Board of Trustees and are included in compensation on Schedule J, Part II, Column (b)(i).

- First Class Travel - The President is authorized to travel in business/first class when flying on Harvey Mudd business. - Travel for companions - With prior approval from the Chairman of the Board of Trustees, the Institution paid for bona fide business related travel expenses for the President's spouse, who is also an employee of the institution. - Housing allowance or residence for personal use - The institution provides lodging for the President and family in institution owned property for the convenience of the employer. The institution provides housing down payment assistance to new faculty and senior staff members. - Personal services - The institution provides cleaning services to the President's house as maintenance of a campus-owned building, which is used for institutional events as well as being the personal residence of the President and family. The institution also pays for phone and cable service to this campus building.

THE UNIVERSITY'S PRESIDENT IS PROVIDED WITH A UNIVERSITY OWNED HOUSE THAT IS SERVICED BY OUR CUSTODIAL, GROUNDS, AND MAINTENANCE DEPARTMENTS. THIS BENEFIT QUALIFIES AS NON-TAXABLE HOUSING PROVIDED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER, UNDER IRC SECTION 119. HEALTH/SOCIAL CLUB DUES ARE PAID ON BEHALF OF THE VP FOR ADVANCEMENT FOR DONOR RELATIONS ACTIVITIES. THE BENEFIT IS INCLUDED IN TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

The First Lady of the University often travels with the President for University business. She serves as executive director of the Samfords Legacy League, an Auxiliary volunteer organization that promotes advocacy for the University and raises scholarship funds. She also serves on the Deans Executive Council for the Universitys School of Education, utilizing her Masters and Doctorate degrees in education and coordinates or participates in certain international programs requiring travel.
The University provides a residence for the Presidents use. The President and First Lady frequently host a significant number of individuals in their home.

The University provides social club dues and fees to five of its officers and key employees. The officers and key employees use the clubs to host University events, and their personal use is de minimus.

Housekeeping services at the Presidents home are provided by a housekeeper who is an employee of the University. These services are considered necessary given the number of University events held at the Presidents home and the fact that all areas, including personal quarters, are open and available for viewing during these events.
One individual received a performance-based bonus during the year. Amounts paid were set in the agreement signed by both parties within their initial contract or a renewal.

Occasionally the President's husband will accompany the President on College fund raising events. The College provides funding for his travel costs. These travel costs are not considered compensation as he is participating in fundraising for the College. Reimbursements for travel cost must follow the College's purchasing and accounts payable policies. These policies include requirements for documentation and receipts. The President is provided housing by the College. The President's house is considered a part of the College's campus and is used for College events and entertaining. The President's housing is considered nontaxable as it is provided for the convenience of the College.

Compensation is reviewed annually. This review includes cost of living statistics, compensation paid for similar positions at other similar colleges, and compensation paid locally for like positions. A standard achievement increase is determined and is approved by the Board of Trustees during the June meeting in conjunction with the approval of the following year's budget. All staff increases are reviewed by the President, Vice Presidents, and heads of departments. The Board of Trustees follows the principal and policies outlined in Knox's executive compensation program as approved May 2, 2016. Compensation for executives of the College is determined by evaluation of a variety of factors, including the skills, tenure, experience and performance of the executive; the difficulty of replacing the executive and the importance of the position to the College; and historical compensation levels and internal pay equity issues. All compensation and other financial benefits for College employees who are Disqualified Persons are to be approved in advance of payment or agreement for payment by the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees.

WHEN THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE TRAVELS AND IT IS PAID FOR BY THE UNIVERSITY, SHE IS PERFORMING DUTIES ON BEHALF OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE PRESIDENT RESIDES IN A UNIVERSITY-OWNED HOUSING, WHICH IS LESS THAN 1/2 MILE FROM MAIN CAMPUS. BY LOCATING HIM IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE UNIVERSITY, IT HELPS TO MAKE THE PRESIDENT AVAILABLE FOR THE DAILY INTERACTION BETWEEN THE COMMUNITY AND THE UNIVERSITY STAFF/STUDENTS/ALUMNI/DONORS AND PHYSICAL PLANTS. THE UNIVERSITY-PROVIDED HOUSING IS GEOGRAPHICALLY INTEGRATED WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S EDUCATIONAL PROPERTY. THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDENCE HAS BEEN OWNED BY THE UNIVERSITY FOR A SUBSTANTIAL NUMBER OF YEARS. PRIOR PRESIDENTS HAVE BEEN REQUIRED TO RESIDE THERE. THE PRESIDENT PERFORMS MANY UNIVERSITY TASKS AND FUNCTIONS AT THE RESIDENCE. THE RESIDENCE IS FURNISHED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY AND IS REQUIRED TO BE OCCUPIED BY THE PRESIDENT AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. AS THE UNIVERSITY'S PRINCIPAL FUND-RAISER, THE PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS ACTUAL OR POTENTIAL BENEFACTORS, VISITING DIGNITARIES AND COMMUNITY LEADERS IN THE RESIDENCE. THE HEAVINESS OF THE PRESIDENT'S ADMINISTRATIVE WORKLOAD, THE PRESENCE OF UNIVERSITY-RELATED SOCIAL FUNCTIONS AND THE NUMBER OF CONFERENCES SCHEDULED WITH STUDENTS OR FACULTY MEMBERS REQUIRE ACCESS TO THE MAJORITY OF THE RESIDENCE. IN ADDITION, THE UNIVERSITY CONDUCTS OTHER EVENTS THAT ARE ESSENTIAL TO ITS EDUCATIONAL EXEMPTION. IN LIEU OF THE AFOREMENTIONED INTRICACIES OF MULTIPLE USES BY MANY MULTIPLE PARTIES INVOLVED, IT IS IMPRACTICAL AND WOULD NOT BE CONSIDERED AN ACCURATE CALCULATION OF THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF QUALIFIED CAMPUS LODGING FURNISHED TO THE PRESIDENT. DUE TO THESE FACTORS, THE UNIVERSITY HAS DECIDED TO OMIT ENTERING THE ESTIMATED AMOUNT OF TAX FREE HOUSING ALLOWANCE PROVIDED IN COLUMN F OF FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN D - "NONTAXABLE BENEFITS". THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES A HOUSE CLEANER FOR THE PRESIDENT AND ALSO PERFORMS ALL NECESSARY MAINTENANCE ON THE HOME. THE PRESIDENT IS ALSO REIMBURSED FOR EXPENSES RELATING TO FINANCIAL SERVICES ADVICE.

The President's compensation is reviewed by the Finance Committee of the Board of Trustees. The Finance Committee combined with the Governance Committee contacted a consultant who performed a comparative analysis to determine that the President's compensation was in line with other institutions. This process was documented in the board minutes upon compensation approval.

The President, Provost and Dean of Students are provided with housing, including maintenance of such space, for the convenience of the employer on the college's premises. The value of the personal space within the housing is included as a nontaxable benefit on Schedule J. The value of the maintenance of the personal space is taxed accordingly. The President is provided with a college vehicle for business use and any personal miles are taxed accordingly. In addition, the President is a member of a local country club for which the college is responsible for the payment of dues. There is no personal use of such clubs.

The Wheaton College Executive Committee, an independent board, establishes compensation to ensure that the Internal Revenue Code provision of "rebuttable presumption of reasonableness" is met and "intermediate sanctions" are not incurred. The Executive Committee obtains and relies upon appropriate data regarding comparability of the compensation package prior to making its determination. Appropriate data includes compensation levels paid by similarly situated organizations, independent compensation surveys by nationally recognized independent firms, and written offers from similar institutions competing for the services of the individual. The Executive Committee documents the basis for its determinations including: the terms of the approved transaction and date approved; the members of the committee who were present during the discussion; and the data obtained and relied upon.

The Former President and his spouse were eligible for a one year sabbatical to be taken immediately following the termination of the President's employment at the College on June 30, 2014. During the sabbatical, they received their then-current base salary and all benefits which they were then receiving.

ELIGIBLE EXECUTIVES PARTICIPATE IN VARIOUS NON-QUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLANS ORGANIZED UNDER CODE SECTION 457(F). THE EXACT PURPOSE OF EACH PLAN VARIES BUT THEY INCLUDE: COMPENSATION LIMITATION MAKE-UP PLANS, VOLUNTARY DEFERRAL PLANS, DEFERRAL OF A PORTION OF INCENTIVE BONUS TYPE PLANS, ETC. ANY AMOUNT ULTIMATELY PAID UNDER THE PROGRAM TO THE EXECUTIVE IS REPORTED AS COMPENSATION ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B IN THE YEAR PAID. NO PAYMENTS WERE MADE TO LISTED PERSONS IN PART VII UNDER THE VARIOUS NON-QUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLANS DURING THE YEAR.

THE BAPTIST MEMORIAL HEALTH CARE SYSTEM HAS ESTABLISHED A MANAGEMENT ACCOUNTABILITY AND FINANCIAL INCENTIVE PLAN THAT ENCOURAGES MANAGEMENT PARTICIPATION IN THE SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENTS OF THE QUALITY, FINANCIAL, GROWTH, AND HUMAN RESOURCE RELATED OPERATIONS OF THE ORGANIZATION. AN INCENTIVE BONUS IS PAID TO ALL MANAGEMENT BASED ON ATTAINMENT OF GOALS IN THE AREAS OF 1) PATIENT SATISFACTION; 2) EMPLOYEE SATISFACTION; 3) PHYSICIAN SATISFACTION; 4) QUALITY AND SAFETY; 5) OPERATIONAL PREFORMANCE METRICS; AND 6) OPERATING INCOME MARGIN. PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE POINTS UNDER A PLAN SCORING SYSTEM FOR MEETING THEIR PREDETERMINED GOALS. THE POINTS ARE THEN ENTERED INTO THE PLAN FORMULA TO DETERMINE THE INCENTIVE COMPENSATION.

The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees chaired by the Board Chairperson deliberates to determine the President's compensation. Each member of the compensation-setting body is a disinterested party. Jesuit members of the Executive Committee recuse themselves from the salary deliberations. Salary data obtained from the Association of Colleges and University Personnel Administrators, the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities and an executive search firm database is used to determine compensation comparability. The decision of the compensation-setting body including terms of the compensation, the date approved, members of the compensation-setting body present during the discussion of the compensation and voting members, comparability data relied on and the source of the data and an affirmation that all members were free of any conflict of interest is documented and retained by the Secretary of the Board of Trustees.
